head.title: Multifaceted Role of a Dibutylhydroxytoluene Processing Additive in Enhancing the Efficiency and Stability of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Multifaceted Role of a Dibutylhydroxytoluene Processing Additive in Enhancing the Efficiency and Stability of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells

Significant research efforts are currently being devoted to improving both the crystalline quality and stability of lead halide perovskite absorbers to advance the commercial prospects of perovskite-based solar cells. Herein, we report a simple one-step dibutylhydroxytoluene (BHT) additive-based approach for simultaneously improving the crystallinity and resistance of perovskite films under adverse degradation conditions. We found that BHT, commonly known for its antioxidant properties, can considerably improve the performance of methylammonium lead iodide perovskite solar cells by modulating the chemical environment within the precursor medium to form intermediate complexes, and it can also suppress photooxidation, which results in perovskite degradation under environmental operating conditions. Consequently, a device exhibited a significant power conversion efficiency improvement to 18.1% with the BHT-additive-based perovskite absorber, exceeding the 17.1% efficiency achieved for the control device. The BHT additive also improved the perovskite stability by quenching intermediate reactions resulting in perovskite degradation to an undesirable lead iodide phase, as evidenced by detailed analysis of absorption spectra, grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering, X-ray photoelectron spectra, and photoluminescence measurements.

SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p: Significant research efforts are currently being devoted to improving both the crystalline quality and stability of lead halide perovskite absorbers to advance the commercial prospects of perovskite-based solar cells. Herein, we report a simple one-step dibutylhydroxytoluene (BHT) additive-based approach for simultaneously improving the crystallinity and resistance of perovskite films under adverse degradation conditions. We found that BHT, commonly known for its antioxidant properties, can considerably improve the performance of methylammonium lead iodide perovskite solar cells by modulating the chemical environment within the precursor medium to form intermediate complexes, and it can also suppress photooxidation, which results in perovskite degradation under environmental operating conditions. Consequently, a device exhibited a significant power conversion efficiency improvement to 18.1% with the BHT-additive-based perovskite absorber, exceeding the 17.1% efficiency achieved for the control device. The BHT additive also improved the perovskite stability by quenching intermediate reactions resulting in perovskite degradation to an undesirable lead iodide phase, as evidenced by detailed analysis of absorption spectra, grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering, X-ray photoelectron spectra, and photoluminescence measurements.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Organic–inorganic halide perovskites (OIHPs) are undeniably promising next-generation energy-harvesting materials for developing solar-based clean energy solutions to the globally surging energy demand.
(1−6)
OIHP photovoltaic devices offer the advantages of low-cost, low-temperature solution processing, low weight, and high mechanical tolerance, which are highly desirable attributes for realizing efficient, flexible, and stretchable optoelectronic devices. During the last few years, intensive research efforts have been devoted to developing perovskite solar cells (PSCs) with respect to both the efficiency and intrinsic physical dynamics of materials and devices. Consequently, the power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of solar cells using this class of photovoltaic materials exceeded the benchmark efficiency of 22% in 2016.
(7)
Various approaches were implemented to improve the performance of PSCs, including multiple cations [methylammonium (MA
+
), formamidinium (FA
+
) Cs
+
, and Rb
+
],
(8−10)
mixed halide anions (Cl
–
, Br
–
, and I
–
),
(11,12)
and morphology engineering involving antisolvent washing, organic/inorganic additives,
(13)
and underlayer abduction.
(14,15)
Achieving high surface coverage of the perovskite absorber by improving the grain size and crystalline quality of the films is a key route to achieving state-of-the-art devices with efficiencies approaching the theoretical maximum. However, perovskite crystallization is a complex process that begins with slow nucleation followed by rapid crystal growth.
(16)
A rapid reaction between the metal halide and organic cations frequently results in poor surface morphology and coverage and perovskite grains with poor crystalline quality, exacerbating recombination mechanisms, and yielding suboptimal photovoltaic metrics.
(17)
Additive-assisted perovskite processing was extensively reported with respect to modulating the perovskite crystallization dynamics to achieve high surface coverage and perovskite grains with good crystalline quality.
(2,18−22)
An additive in the perovskite precursor typically competes in interactions between the precursor components and delays the rapid crystallization; consequently, good surface morphology and coverage with improved grain sizes were observed. Furthermore, the additives were reported to passivate the nonradiative decay channels and enhance the cell performance.

Another major obstacle that currently limits the commercial prospects of PSCs is the long-term stability of the devices under different degradation stresses such as light, air, and elevated temperatures.
(6,23−25)
OIHP absorbers are known to be susceptible to ambient conditions and readily degrade to their chemical subspecies, leaving an undesirable lead iodide (PbI
2
) phase. Methylammonium lead iodide (CH
3
NH
3
PbI
3
, abbreviated as MAPbI
3
), for instance, comprises MA
+
surrounded by an inorganic PbI
2
framework via ionic and hydrogen bonds.
(24)
Under external degradation conditions, the MA
+
can escape the perovskite crystal structure, exposing the bare PbI
2
framework, which is undesirable for photovoltaic applications.
(26)
Thus, the processing additive is expected to not only improve the perovskite morphology, crystallinity, and quality, and passivate the defect states but also increase the stability of the perovskite absorber under adverse operating conditions. In this work, we study dibutylhydroxytoluene (BHT), a sterically hindered phenol, as a single-step processing additive for improving both the performance and stability of PSCs under different stresses. The BHT is commonly used as a stabilizer in commercial polymers such as rubber, polyesters, polyamides, and polyacetals and is also widely used as a food additive due to its antioxidant properties.
(27)
The bond dissociation energy (BDE) of the phenolic hydrogen in BHT is low,
(28)
which inhibits the intermediate decay channels through which the perovskite degrades. Also, the counteranion of the BHT molecule can further interact with the perovskite precursor and thus modulate its growth kinetics. Herein, we report the function of BHT as a perovskite growth mediator and photo-oxidative stabilizer, determined by blending a small amount of the BHT additive with the precursor medium. Consequently, we attained a high PCE of 18.1% in contrast to an efficiency of 17.1% in the control devices fabricated in the n–i–p configuration. Additionally, the enhanced stability of the BHT-incorporated perovskite absorber was demonstrated both by fabricating photovoltaic devices and performing structural and optical characterizations on independent perovskite films. We discuss a detailed mechanism of MAPbI
3
degradation under different stresses and the function of BHT in inhibiting these degradation mechanisms.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Photovoltaic devices were first fabricated in the p–i–n configuration: indium tin oxide (ITO)/poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT:PSS)/MAPbI
3
/phenyl-C
61
-butyric acid methyl ester (PC
61
BM)/ZnO/Al, as shown in the device schematic in
Figure
1
a. The thickness of the perovskite layer was almost 300 nm as estimated from a cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image (
Figure S1
). For the BHT-modified MAPbI
3
(m-MAPbI
3
) films, different molar concentrations were used in the perovskite precursor solution. Brownish black mirrorlike films were obtained for all of the perovskite precursors used; however, the higher concentration of the processing additive resulted in a substandard perovskite film quality. The current density–voltage (
J
–
V
) characteristics of the cells were determined under AM 1.5G solar irradiation.
Figure S2
shows the
J
–
V
characteristics for PSCs with different BHT additive concentrations, and the corresponding photovoltaic parameters are listed in
Table S1
. The
J
–
V
characteristics of the optimized PSCs with pristine MAPbI
3
and m-MAPbI
3
photoactive layers (0.02 M BHT additive), measured under AM 1.5G irradiation, are shown in
Figure
1
b. The detailed photovoltaic parameters, including the short-circuit current density (
J
sc
), open-circuit voltage (
V
oc
), fill factor (FF), and PCE, are listed in
Table
1
. Incorporating the BHT additive into the photovoltaic stack notably enhanced the device performance, with a PCE
max
of 15.2%, a
J
sc
of 20.8 mA cm
–2
, a high
V
oc
of 0.97 V, and a FF of 75.0%, significantly exceeding the photovoltaic parameters of the control device without the additive (PCE
max
: 13.9%,
J
sc
: 19.8 mA cm
–2
,
V
oc
: 0.91 V, and FF: 76.6%). The voltage and current efficiency of the PSCs were primarily benefited by incorporating an optimized quantity of the BHT additive into the perovskite absorber layer. This must originate from the improved crystallinity and reduced carrier traps in the perovskite absorber layer since the charge-transporting layers are the same for both devices.
Figure S3
shows steady-state PCE and current density output characteristics at the maximum power point. The steady-state PCE and corresponding current density show a stable output with values of 13.53% and 17.5 mA cm
–2
for the control device and 14.82% and 18.6 mA cm
–2
for the BHT-added device, respectively. Steady-state PCEs are also close to the values obtained from
J
–
V
measurements. PCE histograms for the PSCs shown in
Figure
1
c show a higher average PCE of 13.4 ± 0.9% for the BHT-containing perovskite devices compared to the pristine devices with an average PCE of 11.9 ± 1.0%. Hence, this demonstrates the efficacy of BHT as a processing additive for fabricating PSCs.
Figure
1
b also shows the
J
–
V
characteristics for the control and modified devices after 30 day storage at 25 °C, at relative humidity (RH) <5%, in ambient light. We observed that the pristine perovskite-based device exhibited a 13% decrease in PCE
max
, in contrast to about 8% in m-MAPbI
3
(both devices were kept without encapsulation), indicating the improved stability of the completed devices. However, we assume that electrode contact degradation and Al metal diffusion might also have contributed to the decreased PCEs, in addition to active layer degradation. To further elucidate the effect of BHT-induced perovskite stabilization, excluding other effects such as contact degradation and metal diffusion, on the device performance, we fabricated PSCs with perovskite precursors aged for 5 and 15 days, stored at 25 °C, RH < 5%, under ambient light. The corresponding
J
–
V
curves are shown in
Figure
1
d. As mentioned previously, the BHT additive can indeed improve the PCEs even in the devices fabricated with aged perovskite precursor solution. Furthermore, we observed that PCE
max
varied only by 3.7 and 8.5% for BHT-containing perovskite precursor aged for 5 and 15 days, respectively, whereas this variation was relatively larger for the aged perovskite precursors without the BHT additive (4.1 and 13%, respectively). Thus, we speculate that the BHT additive also prevented perovskite degradation in the precursor medium, and hence can potentially facilitate bulk fabrication of perovskite devices, since longer storage of the perovskite precursor was often reported to render lower PCEs.
(29)
All of the aforementioned photovoltaic parameters are listed in
Table S2
.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic structure of the fabricated p–i–n-structured PSCs. (b)
J
–
V
characteristics of the PSCs with and without the BHT additive under AM 1.5G illumination. (
#
)
J
–
V
characteristics after storage at 25 °C, RH < 5%, and in ambient light for 30 days. (c) PCE histograms of the studied PSCs. (d)
J
–
V
characteristics for differently aged perovskite precursor solutions with and without the BHT additive. (e) PCE evolution under continuous AM 1.5G solar irradiation. (f) Double logarithmic
J
–
V
plots of pristine and BHT-additive-containing PSCs.

div.div:
Table 1. Photovoltaic Metrics for p–i–n-Structured PSC Devices Based on the BHT Additive
1

div.p: Average values were obtained from at least 24 devices with standard deviations

div.div:
We also explored the effect of the BHT additive on the PCE evolution of photovoltaic devices under continuous solar irradiation of 100 mW cm
–2
with no UV cut filter. Evidently, the BHT processing additive increases both the PCEs of the PSCs and the device lifetime under continuous solar irradiation as exhibited by the slower decay of the PCEs shown in
Figure
1
e. Notably, the PCE for the BHT-containing perovskite device recovered more than 95% of its original value within a short storage period of 45 min in the dark; however, no similar PCE recovery was observed for the pristine devices under similar test and storage conditions. We speculate that, with the BHT additive, the perovskite is rapidly restored to its initial phase after removal of the degradation stress. We suspect that the BHT molecule prevents the MA
+
cation from leaving the crystal structure during light-induced degradation; consequently, the MAI and PbI
2
can reform the photoabsorbing perovskite phase in the dark, and the device efficiency recovers rapidly after the degradation stress is removed.

Moreover, we measured the variation in
J
sc
and
V
oc
with the light intensity for the PSCs as plotted in
Figure S4a,b
.
J
sc
varies linearly as a function of light intensity with similar slopes for the pristine and BHT-modified devices, whereas the semilogarithmic
V
oc
vs light intensity plots yield slopes of 1.94 and 1.73 kT/q, respectively. A higher (kT/q) value for the MAPbI
3
devices reveals that trap-assisted recombination is more predominant in these than in the BHT-modified devices.

To further elucidate the effects of charge transport in the devices, we studied double logarithmic
J
–
V
plots in the dark as shown in
Figure
1
f. Space-charge-limited conduction is reflected in the
J
–
V
characteristics, with different slopes exhibiting different charge transport regimes in the devices.
(30)
Ohmic conduction is observed at low voltages followed by a trap-filled regime at intermediate voltages, suggested by a rapid increase in current density. The transition voltage, often denoted
V
TFL
, is a linear function of the trap state density in photovoltaic devices.
(30)
We estimated
V
TFL
as 0.54 and 0.63 V for PSCs with and without the BHT additive, respectively. A lower trap state density in the perovskite absorber was also evidenced by the improved voltage efficiency of the fabricated devices, which is eventually reflected in the improved PCEs of the BHT-containing MAPbI
3
PSCs.

The BHT-additive-induced PCE improvement was also emulated in the n–i–p-structured photovoltaic devices, a schematic structure of which is shown in
Figure S5a
. The corresponding
J
–
V
characteristics and the photovoltaic parameters are shown in
Figure S5b,c and Table S3
, respectively. Evidently, the incorporation of 0.02 M BHT additive into the MAPbI
3
precursor led to an improvement in the device efficiency from 17.1 to 18.1%, complying with the results obtained for p–i–n-structured devices described above, which ascertains the fact that the BHT additive can improve the perovskite quality and thereby the device performances both in conventional and inverted device structures. The higher external quantum efficiency (EQE) in overall wavelengths represents high
J
sc
from BHT-based perovskite solar cells (
Figure S5d
). The integrated
J
sc
values are well matched with those from
J
–
V
characteristics having the values of 20.5 and 21.1 mA cm
–2
for devices without and with the BHT additive, respectively.

To investigate the improvement mechanism and the change in the chemical environment in the perovskite caused by the BHT additive, we recorded liquid-state proton nuclear magnetic resonance (
1
H NMR) spectra of perovskite precursor solutions with and without BHT in deuterated dimethyl sulfoxide-
d
6
(DMSO-
d
6
) (
Figure S6a
). The solvent peak is marked separately in this figure to distinguish it from the sample signals. In addition to the methyl proton signal in the MA
+
cation at 2.4 ppm, the broad peak centered at δ ∼ 7.34 ppm originates from the three hydrogens bonded to the nitrogen atom in the MA
+
cation. A downfield peak shift is observed for the BHT-containing perovskite precursor solution, as shown in the magnified spectra in
Figure S6b
, which can be attributed to a series of intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the MA
+
and −OH groups of the BHT additive. It is therefore clear that the BHT additive can modify the chemical environment for perovskite growth, thereby affecting the crystalline nature of the perovskite absorber.

Morphology tuning of the perovskite absorber in the presence of organic and inorganic additives has often been shown to enhance the performance parameters of PSCs.
(31)
The SEM was used to study the quality of perovskite films processed with and without the BHT additive. The corresponding low- and high-magnification SEM images are shown in
Figure
2
. Both films exhibit closely packed crystalline domains with a homogenous surface coverage. The effect of the BHT additive concentration on the high-surface-area morphology of the perovskite films is evident in the low-magnification SEM images shown in
Figure S7
. The perovskite films processed with the BHT additive showed homogeneous and clear crystalline grains over a large area in contrast to the pristine perovskite absorber, wherein low-magnification images exhibited fewer brighter domains (
Figure
2
c,d). The brighter plateletlike domains (shown in circles in
Figure
2
a,b) in the pristine perovskite are ascribed to incomplete conversion of the PbI
2
precursor to the desired photoabsorbing perovskite phase, and these can severely undermine the PCE in the devices. The BHT additive modifies the chemical environment in the precursor medium (evidenced by NMR measurements shown in
Figure S6
) and improves the homogeneity of perovskite crystallization during film growth as shown in the large area spot-free SEM images of BHT processed perovskite films. However, we observed that for high concentrations of the BHT additive in the perovskite precursor, the quality of large areas of the perovskite film deteriorated as shown by the appearance of white aggregates in
Figure S7d
. Hence, we speculate that an optimized quantity of the BHT additive can facilitate processing of the perovskite film, whereas excess BHT can lead to phase segregation and reduce the film quality over a larger area, which is also reflected in the poor PCEs at higher BHT concentrations.

div.p:
Figure 2. Top-view SEM images of pristine and BHT-additive-containing MAPbI
3
films under different magnifications. (a, b) Pristine MAPbI
3
. (c, d) MAPbI
3
with 0.02 M BHT.

div.div:
To determine the effect of the BHT additive on the stability of the perovskite films, we studied the optical and X-ray diffraction (XRD) characteristics of pristine and BHT-containing perovskite films under different storage and degradation conditions.
Figures S8 and S9
show the UV–vis absorption and XRD patterns of the as-prepared MAPbI
3
perovskite films processed with and without the BHT additive. Both the films exhibited similar absorption spectra with almost identical absorption onsets at approximately 760 nm. The XRD characteristics shown in
Figure S9
indicate that the inclusion of the BHT additive does not affect the tetragonal crystallinity of the perovskite but improves the crystallinity of the perovskite grains, as evidenced by the increased diffraction intensity in the XRD patterns. A slight decrease in the light-harvesting ability in the absorption range 600–800 nm was observed for perovskite films with no BHT additive on prolonged AM 1.5G solar irradiation for 6 h (
Figure
3
a). A similar decrease in the absorption spectra of the MAPbI
3
films is typically observed under continuous illumination due to the intrinsic instability of the perovskite crystal structure.
(32)
However, we observed that the BHT additive in the perovskite films makes them able to withstand light-induced degradation more efficiently. To further confirm the stability enhancement in the perovskite films achieved by adding an optimized amount of the BHT additive (0.02 M), we determined the change in the light-harvesting ability of the pristine and modified perovskite films under extreme degradation stress. The absorption spectra were recorded after storing the MAPbI
3
films for 24 h and 10 days under 70% RH at 25 °C as shown in
Figure
3
b. The loss of absorbance or the evanescence of the perovskite films upon degradation of the perovskite crystal structure was much more pronounced in the films processed with no BHT additive. Furthermore, the slope of the absorption onset (the inset of
Figure
3
b), which is often related to the Urbach energy, indicating the presence of sub-band-gap (E
g
) states, decreases for the perovskite films with no BHT additive. This indicates that the BHT additive can suppress the formation of tail states near the band gap by inhibiting perovskite degradation under extreme stress. The absorption spectra of the MAPbI
3
film without the additive after 10 days of storage showed the characteristic absorption feature of the PbI
2
precursor (∼500 nm), which was not prominent in the BHT-additive-based perovskite films.
(26)
This indicates that the BHT additive can effectively suppress perovskite degradation by functioning as an antioxidant under different degradation stresses. The evolution of the XRD characteristics of the corresponding perovskite films is shown in
Figure
3
c. The XRD patterns of the pristine and BHT-additive-based perovskite films after 6 h of AM 1.5G solar irradiation show minute variations in the diffraction intensity near 2θ = 12.9° (marked by “●” in the plot) for the pristine perovskite films. These can be envisioned as signature traces of PbI
2
formation upon continuous light soaking.
(33)
However, the m-MAPbI
3
films showed no evidence of PbI
2
formation in their XRD patterns under similar light-soaking conditions. To clarify the BHT-induced perovskite stabilization, we recorded the XRD characteristics of perovskite films stored under different conditions: (i) at 25 °C, RH < 5%, in ambient light for 30 days and (ii) at 25 °C, 70% RH, in ambient light for 15 days. The corresponding XRD patterns are also shown in
Figure
3
c. We observe that, even under mild degradation conditions as in storage (i), the MAPbI
3
films tend to degrade (appearance of signature traces marked by “●” in the plot) possibly by MA
+
escaping from the surface and breaking the perovskite structure, leaving traces of PbI
2
residue. The BHT additive suppresses this phenomenon as evidenced by the XRD patterns of perovskite films under storage conditions (ii), shown by the significantly less intense PbI
2
diffraction peak at ∼12.9° for m-MAPbI
3
. These observations demonstrate the potential ability of the BHT additive to improve the long-term stabilization of the perovskite absorber. The potential interaction between the BHT additive and MAPbI
3
crystal structure is schematically shown in
Figure
3
d.

div.p:
Figure 3. UV–vis absorption spectra of MAPbI
3
films processed with and without the BHT additive (a) after 6 h AM 1.5G solar irradiation and (b) after storage under ambient conditions for different durations (the inset shows the magnified plot in the higher wavelength range). (c) XRD patterns of the perovskite films under different storage conditions: (□) AM 1.5G solar irradiation, (#) RH < 5%, 25 °C, ambient light and (Δ) RH 70%, 25 °C, ambient light (“●” shows the existence of the PbI
2
phase). (d) Schematic of the chemical interaction between the MAPbI
3
perovskite structure and the BHT processing additive.

div.div:
The BHT-induced perovskite phase stabilization was further explored using a highly sensitive grazing-incidence wide-angle X-ray scattering (GIWAXS) method offering two-dimensional (2D) detection capability for probing the crystallographic orientations of the perovskite films in more detail. Pristine and BHT-modified MAPbI
3
samples prepared on SiO
2
/Si substrates were stored under different degradation stresses, i.e., at 25 °C, RH < 5%, in ambient light for 30 days and at 25 °C, RH 70%, in ambient light for 24 h. GIWAXS was used to investigate changes in surface crystalline species with an incident X-ray angle of 0.2° and an estimated penetration depth of ∼125 nm. Both perovskite films showed tetragonal crystallinity, characteristic of MAPbI
3
perovskites at room temperature;
(34)
however, the collected 2D GIWAXS images (
Figure
4
a) showed a trigonal PbI
2
phase in varying amounts, consistent with the conclusions inferred from one-dimensional X-ray diffraction data shown in
Figure
3
c. The azimuthally integrated scattering intensity is plotted against the scattering vector (
q
= 4π sin
θ
/λ) in
Figure
4
b, where θ is half the total scattering angle and λ is the X-ray wavelength (1.123 Å). The scattering peak at
q
= 1 Å
–1
, observed for all of the perovskite samples, is associated with the (110) plane of tetragonal MAPbI
3
perovskites, whereas the peak at
q
= 0.9 Å
–1
is typically assigned to the PbI
2
phase. Evidently, the relative scattering intensity at
q
= 0.9 Å
–1
varies for the pristine and BHT-modified perovskite films on their exposure to different storage conditions for different durations. As shown in
Figure
4
b, the azimuthally integrated scattering intensity associated with the PbI
2
phase is significantly suppressed for the BHT-modified MAPbI
3
, even upon exposure of MAPbI
3
to typical degrading factors such as moisture, air, and ambient light, which is consistent with our assumption of MAPbI
3
perovskite phase stabilization due to incorporation of the BHT processing additive. Moreover, the azimuthal angle intensity distribution of the
q
= 1 Å
–1
perovskite scattering peak shown in
Figure
4
c unexpectedly exhibits a favored out-of-plane orientation for the BHT-additive-containing perovskite films in contrast to their pristine counterparts, which predominantly form with random orientations.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) 2D GIWAXS profiles of pristine and BHT-additive-modified MAPbI
3
perovskite films stored at (#) RH < 5%, 25 °C, ambient light for 30 days and (Δ) RH 70%, 25 °C, ambient light for 24 h. (b) Azimuthally integrated scattering intensity variation with scattering vector
q
for perovskite films under different conditions. (c) Azimuthal angle scattering intensity plot of the
q
= 1 Å
–1
peak from the GIWAXS patterns for pristine and modified perovskites under different storage conditions.

div.div:
Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) measurements were performed on the pristine and BHT-additive-modified perovskite samples to determine the effects of the antioxidant additive on the excited-state dynamics of the perovskites. As shown in
Figure
5
a, adding BHT induces no additional defect states or recombination sites in the perovskite films as evidenced by the similar PL intensities for pristine and modified films. However, as shown in
Figure S10
, the results of TRPL indicated that the PL lifetime of BHT-added perovskite films (34.12 ns) increased two times compared to that of control perovskite films (17.04 ns). These results indicate that the addition of BHT to perovskite improves the perovskite crystallinity and reduces the trap site, thereby reducing the nonradiative recombination inside the perovskite film. Also, two concomitant effects were observed in the excited states of the perovskite after BHT addition: (i) a slight decrease in the emission line width and (ii) a ∼5 meV blue shift in the band-edge emission. Furthermore, the reduced contribution of the deconvoluted PL peak toward the lower-energy side for the BHT-additive-containing perovskite film indicates that there is less radiative recombination (reduced by 26%) due to shallow states near the band edge, which typically reduce the voltage efficiency of photovoltaic devices.
(35)
The above-mentioned effects of the BHT additive on the steady-state PL spectra of the perovskite films suggest that the molecular additive both improves the crystallinity of the perovskite absorber and suppresses the defect states that may lower the open-circuit voltage by exacerbating recombination in completed devices.

div.p:
Figure 5. (a) Steady-state PL spectra of control MAPbI
3
films and BHT-containing MAPbI
3
. Deconvoluted peaks represent the contribution from sub-E
g
states (blue and green peaks represent the fitted sum for the corresponding PL spectra). PL evolution of the perovskite films under a continuous laser excitation (532 nm, 10 μW) for (b) pristine MAPbI
3
and (c) BHT-additive-processed MAPbI
3
.

div.div:
To confirm the effect of BHT on the stability of perovskite films against degradation stresses, we recorded the PL spectra of MAPbI
3
and m-MAPbI
3
films under constant irradiation with a low excitation power (∼10 μW) 532 nm laser. This excitation power was intentionally maintained at lower values to avoid rapid local-heating-induced degradation of the perovskite samples due to the relatively lower thermal conductivity of the perovskite films.
(36)
PL signals from the samples were recorded every 2 min while the perovskite films were kept under a laser beam under ambient conditions (70% RH, 25 °C). The evolution of the PL emission under constant laser power irradiation is shown in
Figure
5
b,c. The PL spectra exhibit a single emission peak under different stages of illumination; however, the changes in the evolution of the PL intensity reveal much information on the light-induced chemical and physical changes occurring in the perovskite films with and without the BHT additive. We observed that both the radiative and nonradiative recombination rates changed under the test conditions as shown by the progressive increases and decreases in the PL intensities of the perovskite films. Both the MAPbI
3
and m-MAPbI
3
films showed a higher PL intensity than their initial value, denoted time—0 min. The increase in the PL intensity of the perovskite can be envisioned as suppression of nonradiative decay channels by the combined effects of laser exposure and ambient moisture. Chemical and structural defects led to trap-assisted recombination of the photoexcited charge carriers in the perovskite films. These trap states formed additional energy levels in the forbidden energy gap and could form both deep and shallow energy levels in the band gap of the perovskite absorber. The deep trap states often accounted for the loss of photogenerated carriers via nonradiative decay channels. Thus, the increase in the PL intensity under continuous exposure to laser power in ambient moisture confirms that the nonradiative deep-level states are passivated in the perovskite films. Such reduction of nonradiative decay paths has also been achieved by postfabrication treatments of samples with water vapor streams for several seconds.
(37)
However, the increased PL intensity is followed by a gradual decrease in the PL emission after a given duration of laser excitation for both perovskite samples. The rate of decrease in the PL emission was much higher in the pristine perovskite in comparison with the BHT-additive-based perovskite films. After an initial increase in the PL emission up to a maximum intensity due to the above-mentioned passivation of the nonradiative decay rate, the PL intensity exhibits a gradual decrease, reaching almost half its initial value after 10 min of laser irradiation. We speculate that the pristine MAPbI
3
structure degrades under continuous laser illumination and ambient moisture to form PbI
2
and subsequently PbO
x
(according to
reactions 1
–
6
), exhibiting much lower radiative efficiency compared with the MAPbI
3
films, emulating the decreased PL intensity of the perovskite films. Concomitantly, we observed a blue shift in the band-edge emission, which was ascribed to the appearance of higher band-gap degradation products such as PbI
2
, PbO
x
, or some intermediate chemical species. However, the m-MAPbI
3
perovskite films exhibited no such drastic evolution of the PL spectra under similar test conditions. We hypothesize that the BHT additive endows the perovskite absorber with higher resistance to degradation stresses. To confirm this hypothesis, we identified the following chemical interactions between the perovskite absorber and the BHT additive in the presence of light and moisture as degrading factors.
(33,38)
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
(5)
(6)
(7)
The perovskite absorber degrades in light and ambient air to form different oxidized species as shown in
reactions 1
–
5
, thereby breaking the perovskite crystal structure and leading to suboptimal functioning of photovoltaic devices. The BHT additive can inhibit degradation by quenching oxidized species at the intermediate stages as shown in
reaction 2
. In the BHT molecular additive, hydrogen is easily extracted from the phenolic site due to its extremely low BDE of 78.48 kcal mol
–1
;
(28)
hence, it can function as a chain terminator in the initial stages of the degradation reaction. We speculate that the perovskite degradation is initiated by the formation of photogenerated transient charge-transfer excited states [Pb
+
... I°] in the light, ultimately leading to I
2
, which can easily escape the perovskite structure. The unstable Pb
+
species tend to react with oxygen in the air, which can easily diffuse into the perovskite. Reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as O
2–
and HO
2
–
, may be generated, which can further oxidize the iodides, generating I
2
and OH
–
ions as shown in
reaction 2
. Hydroxyl ions are known to slowly deprotonate the ammonium ions, which typically results in the escape of low-boiling-point methylammonium from the crystal structure, forming PbI
2
crystals both on the surface and in the bulk. Subsequently, PbI
2
may further react with oxygen in the air to form PbO and I
2
(
reaction 6
). The decreased PL emission and shifting of the band-edge emission confirm the formation of PbI
2
and/or PbO
x
as degradation products. The BHT additive achieves photo-oxidative stabilization of the perovskite absorber owing to its ability to quench generated free radical species by donating its freely available hydrogen attached to its hydroxyl site. This easily extractable hydrogen can effectively terminate the degradation reaction by neutralizing ROS during the intermediate stages and therefore preventing iodide oxidation and deprotonation of ammonium ions. We also speculate that the BHT additive can inhibit transformation of the unstable Pb
+
species to metallic Pb.

The above hypothesis of BHT-induced perovskite stabilization was also investigated by exposing the perovskite precursors processed with and without the BHT additive to ambient conditions (25 °C, RH 70%, ambient light) for 12 h. We observed that the surface region of the pristine perovskite precursor turned reddish-brown after 12 h of ambient exposure; this did not occur with the BHT-containing perovskite precursor (
Figure S11a
). We speculate that the appearance of the reddish-brown tint in the surface region was due to lead oxide (PbO
x
) formation, possibly from the reaction of PbI
2
with air (
reaction 6
). The process was suppressed by the BHT additive and was evident only after prolonged exposure of the precursor to air and light (15 days,
Figure S11b
). These results, along with the PL evolution upon continuous laser illumination, confirm that both the perovskite film and the precursor itself are extremely susceptible to storage conditions and readily degrade to other chemical species. The BHT processing additive stabilizes the perovskite and can potentially enhance the stability of both the film and the precursor medium, as evidenced by the
J
–
V
characteristics of the corresponding PSCs discussed in detail previously.

Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on fresh perovskite films and those stored for 12 h at 25 °C, RH 70%, in ambient light to investigate the inherent compositional changes in the perovskite on degradation.
Figure
6
shows the Pb 4f core-level spectra of pristine and m-MAPbI
3
films after compensating for C 1s at 284.6 eV. No discernible spectral differences were observed between the as-prepared perovskite films with and without the BHT additive (
Figure
6
a,b); however, different chemical states with different relative compositions were evident in the perovskite films stored under the aforementioned conditions. The peaks at higher binding energies (B.E.) of ∼137 eV are assigned to Pb–I compounds in the perovskite in accordance with the previous literature.
(33)
The lower B.E. peak at ∼135.6 eV can be ascribed to metallic Pb (Pb
0
) in the top 5–6 nm of the perovskite films. The relative compositions of the compounds indicate metallic lead, and their evolution under degradation conditions was estimated by fitting the XPS spectra as shown in
Figure
6
c. The relative percentage of Pb
0
species in the pristine perovskite films was estimated as 32%, whereas we observed no similar emergence of lower B.E. peaks for the m-MAPbI
3
films under the studied storage time (
Figure
6
d). We speculate that unstable Pb
+
in the transient charge-transfer excited states [Pb
+
... I°], which typically form during the initial degradation stages (
reaction 1
), can be reduced to metallic lead, creating additional carrier trap states in the perovskite layer. It has also been reported that PbI
2
can transform to metallic lead (Pb
0
) in the light, with I
2
escaping from the perovskite structure (
reaction 7
).
(33)
The BHT additive in the perovskite may suppress the Pb
+
to Pb
0
transition, as observed via the XPS measurements. This can significantly reduce the carrier trap density and improve the voltage efficiency of the devices.

div.p: Figure 6. XPS spectra of Pb 4f core levels of pristine and BHT-additive-containing perovskite films. (a, b) As prepared and (c, d) after 12 h storage at 25 °C, RH 70%, in ambient light.

div.div:
Additionally, we explored the thermal stability of PSCs with and without the BHT additive. The thermal stability test was carried out at 100 °C in N
2
-filled glovebox conditions. As shown in
Figure S12
, the PCE of pristine devices decreased to ∼30% of its original value, whereas the BHT-modified devices could preserve ∼60% of their initial performance after 30 h under the same test conditions. This result along with the detailed electrical and optical measurements described above corroborates our findings that the presence of the BHT additive improves the overall performance as well as the stability of the PSCs under degradation stress conditions.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we have demonstrated a facile but effective one-step route to improving the efficiency of PSCs employing a MAPbI
3
absorber while endowing perovskite films with improved resistance against degradation stresses such as light, air, and moisture. BHT, a commercially available and widely used photooxidation stabilizer, was used as a processing additive in the perovskite precursor, and its roles in modulating the film crystallinity, reducing the sub-Eg states and carrier traps, and inhibiting perovskite degradation under different stresses were comprehensively studied. The PCE of the MAPbI
3
solar cells fabricated in the n–i–p configuration increased to 18.1% for the BHT-additive-containing perovskite devices in contrast to 17.1% for the control devices without the additive. Furthermore, the improved resistance of the perovskite absorber with the BHT additive was studied using PL, XPS, XRD, and UV–vis measurements, and a mechanism for photooxidation inhibition in the perovskite was proposed. Hence, we report a new additive-based approach to improving both the device efficiency and the film stability against different degrading factors, which frequently limit the practical application of perovskite-based devices.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All chemicals were purchased from Dyesol, Alfa Aesar, and Acros and used without further purification. The PSCs were fabricated on ITO glass substrates. Prior to the device fabrication, the laser-patterned ITO substrates were cleaned sequentially in detergent, deionized (DI) water, acetone, and isopropanol by ultrasonication for 20 min at each step. The cleaned ITO substrates were dried under a nitrogen flow and UV–ozone-treated before the deposition of the PEDOT:PSS hole-transporting interlayer. The PEDOT:PSS (Al 4083) was spin-coated onto the ITO substrates at 4000 rpm for 60 s and subsequently dried at 140 °C for 20 min. MAPbI
3
precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 645 mg of PbI
2
and 222 mg of MAI in a mixed solvent of γ-butyrolactone (700 μL) and DMSO (300 μL). For modification with the BHT additive, different molar concentrations of BHT dissolved in the DMSO solvent were added into the perovskite precursor solution. A two-step spin-coating sequence was used to coat the perovskite films onto the PEDOT:PSS-coated ITO substrates: 1000 rpm for 10 s followed by 4000 rpm for 30 s. Toluene (800 μL) was dropped on rotating the substrates at an optimized speed and from an optimized distance 5 s before the end of the spin-coating. Subsequently, the perovskite films were dried initially at 60 °C for 1 min and then at 100 °C for 5 min to obtain the desired photoabsorbing perovskite phase. PCBM (20 mg mL
–1
in chlorobenzene) and ZnO NPs dispersion in isopropanol (2.5 wt %, Nanograde AG, Produce N-10) were deposited sequentially onto the perovskite layer at a spin speed of 4000 rpm for 45 s to form a bilayer electron-transporting system. Afterward, the films were additionally annealed at 100 °C for 5 min. Finally, the photovoltaic devices were completed by the deposition of the Al electrode (100 nm) under high vacuum conditions (1 × 10
–6
mbar).

Prepatterned fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass substrates were cleaned using the same procedure as used for the ITO glass substrate cleaning. The compact TiO
2
film was deposited onto FTO via spin-coating at 2000 rpm for 60 s using diluted titanium diisopropoxide (Sigma-Aldrich) and dried at 125 °C for 5 min. Subsequently, a mesoporous TiO
2
layer was deposited by spin-coating diluted TiO
2
paste (Dyesol, 30 NR-D) at 4000 rpm for 60 s and subsequently annealed at 500 °C for 30 min. TiO
2
-coated substrates were immersed in 0.02 M titanium tetrachloride (TiCl
4
) solution at 70 °C for 20 min and annealed again at 500 °C for 30 min to passivate defect sites on the TiO
2
surface. The MAPbI
3
film was prepared through the same process as p–i–n-structured solar cell fabrication methods. The hole transport layer solution was prepared by dissolving 72.3 mg of spiro-OMeTAD in chlorobenzene and adding 28.8 μL of 4-tertbutylpyridine and 17.5 μL of lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Li-TFSI) solution (520 mg of Li-TFSI in 1 mL of acetonitrile) to the prepared solution. Then, spiro-OMeTAD solution was deposited by spin-coating at 4000 rpm for 60 s. Finally, gold (Au) electrodes (100 nm) were deposited by thermal evaporation under high vacuum conditions to complete the photovoltaic devices.

The
J
–
V
characteristics of the photovoltaic devices were recorded in a N
2
-filled glovebox using a Keithley 2365A source measure unit under simulated irradiation of 100 mW cm
–2
. The EQE measurement was carried out under ambient conditions (QEX7, PV measurements). For surface morphology measurements, the samples were characterized using a scanning electron microscope S-4800, Hitachi. The excited-state dynamics of the perovskite absorber was recorded by an alpha300R WITec PL setup. The absorption spectra of the perovskite films were recorded using a Cary 5000 (Varian) spectrophotometer. For XRD, the perovskite films were prepared on glass substrates and characterized using MAX 2500, Rigaku XRD measurement unit using a Cu X-ray source. The GIWAXS measurement on the perovskite samples was carried out using the PLS-II 9A U-SAXS beam line at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL), Korea. Rayonix SX165, a 2D CCD detector, was used to record the X-ray scattering signal, where the incident X-ray had a wavelength of 1.123 Å. The liquid-state
1
H NMR spectra of the perovskite solution in deuterated DMSO-
d
6
solvent were recorded by a VNMRS 400 MHz spectrophotometer.

Promises and challenges of perovskite solar cells
Correa-Baena, Juan-Pablo; Saliba, Michael; Buonassisi, Tonio; Graetzel, Michael; Abate, Antonio; Tress, Wolfgang; Hagfeldt, Anders

A review is given. The efficiencies of perovskite solar cells have gone from single digits to a certified 22.1% in a few years' time. At this stage of their development, the key issues concern how to achieve further improvements in efficiency and long-term stability. We review recent developments in the quest to improve the current state of the art. Because photocurrents are near the theor. max., our focus is on efforts to increase open-circuit voltage by improving charge-selective contacts and charge carrier lifetimes in perovskites via processes such as ion tailoring. The challenges assocd. with long-term perovskite solar cell device stability include the role of testing protocols, ionic movement affecting performance metrics over extended periods of time, and detn. of the best ways to counteract degrdn. mechanisms.

The inverted perovskite solar cell fabricated using a two-step method exhibited the highest FF of 0.85 and good efficiency of 18% based on CH3NH3PbI3. A small amt. of H2O was added into PbI2/DMF to make a homogeneous precursor soln. A high quality PbI2 film with full coverage was formed on a PEDOT:PSS surface by spin coating of the homogeneous PbI2 precursor soln. The perovskite film fabricated from the high quality PbI2 film is highly pure, smooth and very dense even without any pinhole. The champion cell achieves a remarkable fill factor (FF) of 0.85, which is the highest value reported in perovskite solar cells. The FF value is also very reproducible with less than 10% deviation for 50 cells. The cell exhibits no current hysteresis and is stable under both dark and illumination conditions in dry and inert atmospheres. The results not only provide a strategy to fabricate high efficiency inverted perovskite solar cells but also reveal how the water additive in the PbI2/DMF soln. may affect the properties of PbI2 and therefore the perovskite film prepd. using the two-step method and the overall photovoltaic performance of the corresponding inverted solar cell.

Even though the mesoporous-type perovskite solar cell (PSC) is known for high efficiency, its planar-type counterpart exhibits lower efficiency and hysteretic response. Herein, we report success in suppressing hysteresis and record efficiency for planar-type devices using EDTA-complexed tin oxide (SnO2) electron-transport layer. The Fermi level of EDTA-complexed SnO2 is better matched with the conduction band of perovskite, leading to high open-circuit voltage. Its electron mobility is about three times larger than that of the SnO2. The record power conversion efficiency of planar-type PSCs with EDTA-complexed SnO2 increases to 21.60% (certified at 21.52% by Newport) with negligible hysteresis. Meanwhile, the low-temperature processed EDTA-complexed SnO2 enables 18.28% efficiency for a flexible device. Moreover, the unsealed PSCs with EDTA-complexed SnO2 degrade only by 8% exposed in an ambient atmosphere after 2880 h, and only by 14% after 120 h under irradiation at 100 mW cm(-2).

Org.-inorg. hybrid solar cells that combine a mesoporous scaffold, a perovskite light absorber and an org. hole transporter have emerged at the forefront of soln.-processable photovoltaic devices; however, they require processing temps. of up to 500 °C to sinter the mesoporous metal-oxide support. The energy costs assocd. with sepg. tightly bound excitons (photoinduced electron-hole pairs) and extg. free charges from highly disordered low-mobility networks represent fundamental losses for many low-cost photovoltaic technologies. A low-cost, soln.-processable solar cell is reported, based on a highly cryst. perovskite absorber with intense visible to near-IR absorptivity, that has a power conversion efficiency of 10.9% in a single-junction device under simulated full sunlight. This "meso-superstructured solar cell" exhibits exceptionally few fundamental energy losses; it can generate open-circuit photovoltages of more than 1.1 V, despite the relatively narrow absorber band gap of 1.55 eV. The functionality arises from the use of mesoporous alumina as an inert scaffold that structures the absorber and forces electrons to reside in and be transported through the perovskite.

Photovoltaic technol. requires light-absorbing materials that are highly efficient, lightwt., low cost and stable during operation. Organolead halide perovskites constitute a highly promising class of materials, but suffer limited stability under ambient conditions without heavy and costly encapsulation. Here, we report ultrathin (3 μm), highly flexible perovskite solar cells with stabilized 12% efficiency and a power-per-wt. as high as 23 W/g. To facilitate air-stable operation, we introduce a chromium oxide-chromium interlayer that effectively protects the metal top contacts from reactions with the perovskite. The use of a transparent polymer electrode treated with dimethylsulfoxide as the bottom layer allows the deposition-from soln. at low temp.-of pinhole-free perovskite films at high yield on arbitrary substrates, including thin plastic foils. These ultra-lightwt. solar cells are successfully used to power aviation models. Potential future applications include unmanned aerial vehicles-from airplanes to quadcopters and weather balloons-for environmental and industrial monitoring, rescue and emergency response, and tactical security applications.

We report on the fabrication and opto-electronic characterization of soln.-processed planar heterojunction perovskite solar cells based on methylammonium (MA) lead halide derivs., MAPbI3-xYx (Y = Cl, Br, I). Dissolving equimolar amts. of lead iodide (PbI2) and methylammonium iodide (H3CNH3I) together with various amts. of addnl. methylammonium halides, perovskite precursor solns. were obtained, which were used in the fabrication of three perovskite systems, MAPbI3, MAPbI3-xClx and MAPbI3-xBrx. The effect of the halide ratio in the perovskite formulations processed via a one-step deposition technique on optoelectronic properties and on photovoltaic performance of the formed perovskites was investigated. The perovskite film morphol., temp.-dependent photoluminescence properties, hysteresis behavior in current-voltage characteristics and the photovoltaic performance as a function of chem. compn. were studied using microscopic, spectroscopic and photovoltaic characterization techniques. The power conversion efficiency was dependent on MAPbI3-xYx (Y = Cl, Br, I) perovskite film morphol. By controlling perovskite precursor compn. and stoichiometry, highest power conversion efficiencies of 9.2, 12.5 and 5.4% were obtained for MAPbI3, MAPbI3-xClx and MAPbI3-xBrx devices, resp. In addn., the phys. parameters of the mixed halide perovskites such as the exciton binding energy, exciton-phonon interaction and bandgap were detd. via temp.-dependent photoluminescence spectroscopy. Exciton binding and optical phonon energies of MAPbI3-xYx (Y = Cl, Br, I) were in the ranges of 49-68 meV and 29-32 meV resp. The soln.-processed MA lead halide derivs. form highly cryst. materials with chem. versatility allowing the tuning of their optical and electronic properties depending on the nature and the ratio of the halides employed.

Zarick, Holly F.; Soetan, Naiya; Erwin, William R.; Bardhan, Rizia

Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have improved at an unprecedented rate, reaching over 22% power conversion efficiency in less than a decade, and have generated a wealth of high impact work in the literature studying the properties of these unique materials. While the highest performance and best progress have been obsd. with methylammonium lead triiodide perovskites, their low tolerance to moisture and rapid degrdn. when exposed to UV light and high temps. have posed a major setback to their commercialization. Recently, mixed halide hybrid perovskites (MHHPs) where I- is substituted with Br- and Cl- have driven a paradigm shift in PSCs, synergistically combining high performance with high ambient stability. In this comprehensive review, we summarize the progress made in the past 5 years in methylammonium-based org.-inorg. MHHPs and cesium-based all inorg. MHHPs. We discuss the fabrication approaches for halide substitution and the resulting crystal structure, long-term stability and durability, and device performance. Unique from other reviews, we focus this review on the optical properties of MHHPs, including light-induced phase segregation and alterations in the optical band gap and photoluminescence with halide substitution. We also summarize trends in carrier dynamics, including carrier thermalization, recombination, and charge transfer probed with time-resolved optical spectroscopies. Furthermore, we provide a short overview on mixed cation hybrid perovskites, where methylammonium is substituted with formamidinium/cesium or Pb is substituted with less toxic and benign metals to improve both the stability and the environmental impact of PSCs. We discuss the optical characteristics of mixed cation perovskites and approaches to lower nonradiative recombination with cation substitution. We conclude this review with a discussion on innovative future directions that will propel research on MHHPs as a game changer in perovskite-based optoelectronics.

Organolead trihalide perovskite materials have been successfully used as light absorbers in efficient photovoltaic cells. Two different cell structures, based on mesoscopic metal oxides and planar heterojunctions have already demonstrated very impressive advances in performance. Here, we report a bilayer architecture comprising the key features of mesoscopic and planar structures obtained by a fully soln.-based process. We used CH3NH3 Pb(I1 - xBrx)3 (x = 0.1-0.15) as the absorbing layer and poly(triarylamine) as a hole-transporting material. The use of a mixed solvent of γ-butyrolactone and dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) followed by toluene drop-casting leads to extremely uniform and dense perovskite layers via a CH3NH3I-PbI2-DMSO intermediate phase, and enables the fabrication of remarkably improved solar cells with a certified power-conversion efficiency of 16.2% and no hysteresis. These results provide important progress towards the understanding of the role of soln.-processing in the realization of low-cost and highly efficient perovskite solar cells.

Hybrid org./lead halide perovskites are promising materials for solar cell fabrication, resulting in efficiencies up to 18%. The most commonly studied perovskites are CH3NH3PbI3 and CH3NH3PbI3-xClx where x is small. Importantly, in the latter system, the presence of chloride ion source in the starting solns. used for the perovskite deposition results in a strong increase in the overall charge diffusion length. In this work we investigate the crystn. parameters relevant to fabrication of perovskite materials based on CH3NH3PbI3 and CH3NH3PbBr3. We find that the addn. of PbCl2 to the solns. used in the perovskite synthesis has a remarkable effect on the end product, because PbCl2 nanocrystals are present during the fabrication process, acting as heterogeneous nucleation sites for the formation of perovskite crystals in soln. We base this conclusion on SEM studies, synthesis of perovskite single crystals, and on cryo-TEM imaging of the frozen mother liq. Our studies also included the effect of different substrates and substrate temps. on the perovskite nucleation efficiency. In view of our findings, we optimized the procedures for solar cells based on lead bromide perovskite, resulting in 5.4% efficiency and Voc of 1.24 V, improving the performance in this class of devices. Insights gained from understanding the hybrid perovskite crystn. process can aid in rational design of the polycryst. absorber films, leading to their enhanced performance.

Following pioneering work, soln.-processable org.-inorg. hybrid perovskites-such as CH3NH3PbX3 (X = Cl, Br, I)-have attracted attention as light-harvesting materials for mesoscopic solar cells. So far, the perovskite pigment has been deposited in a single step onto mesoporous metal oxide films using a mixt. of PbX2 and CH3NH3X in a common solvent. However, the uncontrolled pptn. of the perovskite produces large morphol. variations, resulting in a wide spread of photovoltaic performance in the resulting devices, which hampers the prospects for practical applications. Here we describe a sequential deposition method for the formation of the perovskite pigment within the porous metal oxide film. PbI2 is first introduced from soln. into a nanoporous titanium dioxide film and subsequently transformed into the perovskite by exposing it to a soln. of CH3NH3I. We find that the conversion occurs within the nanoporous host as soon as the two components come into contact, permitting much better control over the perovskite morphol. than is possible with the previously employed route. Using this technique for the fabrication of solid-state mesoscopic solar cells greatly increases the reproducibility of their performance and allows us to achieve a power conversion efficiency of approx. 15 per cent (measured under std. AM1.5G test conditions on solar zenith angle, solar light intensity and cell temp.). This two-step method should provide new opportunities for the fabrication of soln.-processed photovoltaic cells with unprecedented power conversion efficiencies and high stability equal to or even greater than those of today's best thin-film photovoltaic devices.

Perovskite solar cells are well known to degrade under post-fabrication stress, among others due to humidity as a consequence of the hydrophilic properties of the org. cation. On the other hand, it has been shown that the controlled addn. of water mols. during the formation of the perovskite (while starting from water-free precursor materials) yields larger perovskite crystals with less defects, resulting in better device performance. One aspect still missing in this line of research is the water content of the perovskite precursors themselves: although most of them are prepd. with anhyd. solvents as a precaution towards premature degrdn., it is still unclear whether or not the precursors really need to be dry. In this paper, the impact of the perovskite precursor's water content up to 10 vol% is investigated, in the form of a detailed study regarding the opto-electronic and morphol. properties of the resulting films and devices. It is found that only modest changes occur in the films that do not affect the final photovoltaic performance, thus relaxing the conditions for large-scale prodn. of this upcoming photovoltaic technol.

Org.-inorg. metal halide perovskites have recently emerged as a top contender to be used as an absorber material in highly efficient, low-cost photovoltaic devices. Soln.-processed semiconductors tend to have a high d. of defect states and exhibit a large degree of electronic disorder. Perovskites appear to go against this trend, and despite relatively little knowledge of the impact of electronic defects, certified solar-to-elec. power conversion efficiencies of up to 17.9% have been achieved. Here, through treatment of the crystal surfaces with the Lewis bases thiophene and pyridine, the authors demonstrate significantly reduced nonradiative electron-hole recombination within the MeNH3PbI3-xClx perovskite, achieving photoluminescence lifetimes which are enhanced by nearly an order of magnitude, up to 2 μs. Probably this is due to the electronic passivation of under-coordinated Pb atoms within the crystal. Through this method of Lewis base passivation, the authors achieve power conversion efficiencies for soln.-processed planar heterojunction solar cells enhanced from 13% for the untreated solar cells to 15.3% and 16.5% for the thiophene and pyridine-treated solar cells, resp.

The large photocurrent hysteresis obsd. in many organometal trihalide perovskite solar cells has become a major hindrance impairing the ultimate performance and stability of these devices, while its origin was unknown. Here we demonstrate the trap states on the surface and grain boundaries of the perovskite materials to be the origin of photocurrent hysteresis and that the fullerene layers deposited on perovskites can effectively passivate these charge trap states and eliminate the notorious photocurrent hysteresis. Fullerenes deposited on the top of the perovskites reduce the trap d. by two orders of magnitude and double the power conversion efficiency of CH3NH3PbI3 solar cells. The elucidation of the origin of photocurrent hysteresis and its elimination by trap passivation in perovskite solar cells provides important directions for future enhancements to device efficiency.

The effect is investigated of the combination of two emerging materials, heteroatom-doped graphene oxide and org.-inorg. lead halide perovskite in the active layer of the solar cells. By introducing N-doped reduced graphene oxide (N-RGO) to the perovskite layer through dispersing it in the precursor soln., all the photovoltaic parameters were improved, which resulted in an improvement of the PCE from 17.3-18.7%. The improved fill factor and Jsc are attributed mainly to the larger grains and thicker perovskite layer, which reduces the grain boundaries and improves light-harvesting properties. The 1H NMR spectra showed that the basic nitrogen groups on N-RGO interact with formamidinium cations in the blended perovskite soln. resulting in enlarged grain size. On the other hand, the increase in VOC is ascribed to surface-passivation of the perovskite by graphene sheets resulting in improved hole selectivity and reduced recombination at the perovskite/spiro interface. This is the first time that N-RGO has been used in perovskite solar cells to tune both morphol. features and recombination dynamics. The introduction of this heteroatom-doped graphene as surface passivation and perovskite grain growth agent in the perovskite layer offers a new and effective tool towards the improvement of the perovskite solar cells.

In addn. to the known effect of the substrate on the interfacial properties of perovskite films, here we show that the bulk properties of hybrid lead halide perovskite films depend on the type of substrate used for film growth. Despite the relative large film thickness, ∼600 nm, the roughness and nature of the substrate layer (glass, FTO, TiO2 and PEDOT:PSS) affect not just the degree of preferential orientation and crystal grain size but also the lattice parameters of CH3NH3PbI3 films synthesized from the PbCl2 precursor. The obtained changes in lattice parameters indicate that the Pb-Pb distance varies by around 0.7%. We suggest that the substrate roughness and chem. nature det. the concn. of defects mainly by varying the chlorine content and probably by the incorporation of oxygen and iodine vacancies during film nucleation and growth. These differences also have consequences in the obsd. light induced transformations. Upon laser illumination, the formation of addnl. defects, most probably related to oxygen, is revealed by 110 and 165 cm-1 Raman peaks. With increasing laser power the chem. transformation into PbOx is clearly identified by the 140 and 275 cm-1 Raman peaks. The irreversible photoluminescence enhancement obsd. at low power with illumination time, also dependent on the substrate nature, is proposed to be due to the localization of the electron-hole excitons created in the vicinity of the light generated defects. These results shed light on the performance of the perovskite layer and help to understand how bulk processes, where ion migration is a conspicuous example, are severely affected by interfacial properties such as those imposed by the substrate.

Organometal halide perovskite materials are presently some of the pacesetters for light harvesting in hybrid photovoltaic devices because of their excellent inherent elec. and optical properties. However, long-term durability of such perovskite materials remains a major bottleneck for their commercialization esp. in countries with hot and humid climatic conditions, thus violating the international stds. for photovoltaic technol. Albeit, TiO2 as an electron-transport layer has been well investigated for perovskite solar cells; the high-temp. processing makes it unsuitable for low-cost and large-scale roll-to-roll prodn. of flexible photovoltaic devices. Herein, we have chosen low-temp. (<150 °C)-processable nanostructured ZnO as the electron-selective layer and used a two-step method for sensitizing ZnO nanorods with methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3) perovskite, which is viable for flexible photovoltaic devices. We have also elaborately addressed the effect of the annealing duration on the conversion of a precursor soln. into the required perovskite phase on ZnO nanostructures. The investigations show that the presence of ZnO nanostructures accelerates the rate of degrdn. of MAPbI3 films under ambient annealing and thus requires proper optimization. The role of ZnO in enhancing the degrdn. kinetics of the perovskite layer has been investigated by XPS and a buffer layer passivation technique. The effect of the annealing duration of the MAPbI3 perovskite on the optical, morphol., and compositional behavior has been closely studied and correlated with the photovoltaic efficiency. The study captures the degrdn. behavior of the com. interesting MAPbI3 perovskite on a ZnO electron-transport layer and thus can provide insight for developing alternative families of perovskite material with better thermal and environmental stability for application in low-cost flexible photovoltaic technol.

A review. Hindered phenols find a wide variety of applications across many different industry sectors. Butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT) is a most commonly used antioxidant recognized as safe for use in foods contg. fats, pharmaceuticals, petroleum products, rubber and oil industries. In the past two decades, there has been growing interest in finding novel antioxidants to meet the requirements of these industries. To accelerate the antioxidant discovery process, researchers have designed and synthesized a series of BHT derivs. targeting to improve its antioxidant properties to be having a wide range of antioxidant activities markedly enhanced radical scavenging ability and other phys. properties. Accordingly, some structure-activity relationships and rational design strategies for antioxidants based on BHT structure have been suggested and applied in practice. We have identified 14 very sensitive parameters, which may play a major role on the antioxidant performance of BHT. In this review, we attempt to summarize the current knowledge on this topic, which is of significance in selecting and designing novel antioxidants using a well-known antioxidant BHT as a building-block mol. Our strategy involved investigation on understanding the chem. behind the antioxidant activities of BHT, whether through hydrogen or electron transfer mechanism to enable promising anti-oxidant candidates to be synthesized.

An antioxidant mechanism of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and cannabidiol (CBD) were compared with a simplified model of α-tocopherol, butylhydroxytoluene and hydroxytoluene in order to understand the antioxidant nature of THC and CBD mols. using DFT. An important factor that shows an influence in the antioxidant property of THC is the electron abstraction at the phenol position. Our data indicate that the decrease of the HOMO values and the highest ionization potential values are related to phenol, ether, and alkyl moieties. Whereas the promise of metal halide perovskite (MHP) photovoltaics (PV) is that they can combine high efficiency with soln.-processability, the chem. occurring in precursor inks is largely unexplored. Herein, the degrdn. is investigated of MHP solns. based on the most widely used solvents, DMF and DMSO. For the MHP inks studied, which contain formamidinium (FA+), methylammonium (MA+), cesium (Cs+), lead (Pb2+), bromide (Br-), and iodide (I-), dramatic compositional changes are obsd. following storage of the inks in nitrogen in the dark. It is shown that hydrolysis of DMF in the precursor soln. forms dimethylammonium formate, which subsequently incorporates into the MHP film to compromise the ability of Cs+ and MA+ to stabilize FA+-based MHP. The changes in soln. chem. lead to a modification of the perovskite film stoichiometry, band gap, and structure. The solid precursor salts are stable when ball-milled into a powder, allowing for the storage of large quantities of stoichiometric precursor materials.

The fundamental properties and ultimate performance limits of organolead trihalide MAPbX3 (MA = CH3NH3+; X = Br- or I-) perovskites remain obscured by extensive disorder in polycryst. MAPbX3 films. The authors report an antisolvent vapor-assisted crystn. approach that enables the authors to create sizable crack-free MAPbX3 single crystals with vols. exceeding 100 cubic millimeters. These large single crystals enabled a detailed characterization of their optical and charge transport characteristics. The authors obsd. exceptionally low trap-state densities ∼109 to 1010 per cubic centimeter in MAPbX3 single crystals (comparable to the best photovoltaic-quality silicon) and charge carrier diffusion lengths exceeding 10 μm. These results were validated with d. functional theory calcns.

High-efficiency solution-processed perovskite solar cells with millimeter-scale grains
Nie, Wanyi; Tsai, Hsinhan; Asadpour, Reza; Blancon, Jean-Christophe; Neukirch, Amanda J.; Gupta, Gautam; Crochet, Jared J.; Chhowalla, Manish; Tretiak, Sergei; Alam, Muhammad A.; Wang, Hsing-Lin; Mohite, Aditya D.

State-of-the-art photovoltaics use high-purity, large-area, wafer-scale single-cryst. semiconductors grown by sophisticated, high-temp. crystal growth processes. We demonstrate a soln.-based hot-casting technique to grow continuous, pinhole-free thin films of organometallic perovskites with millimeter-scale cryst. grains. We fabricated planar solar cells with efficiencies approaching 18%, with little cell-to-cell variability. The devices show hysteresis-free photovoltaic response, which had been a fundamental bottleneck for the stable operation of perovskite devices. Characterization and modeling attribute the improved performance to reduced bulk defects and improved charge carrier mobility in large-grain devices. We anticipate that this technique will lead the field toward synthesis of wafer-scale cryst. perovskites, necessary for the fabrication of high-efficiency solar cells, and will be applicable to several other material systems plagued by polydispersity, defects, and grain boundary recombination in soln.-processed thin films.

The stability of CH3NH3PbI3 was investigated by observing the degrdn. in a coevaporated film irradiated by a blue laser in ultrahigh vacuum. XPS and SEM (SEM) were employed to investigate the effects of irradn. on the surface. The core levels of CH3NH3PbI3 were obsd. to shift toward a higher binding energy (BE) during the irradn., suggesting that the surface became more n-type. A new metallic Pb component in the XPS spectrum appeared after 120 min of irradn., indicating that the film had started to decomp. The decompn. satd. after about 480 min of irradn. when the ratio of metallic Pb to total Pb was about 33%. Furthermore, the film was no longer continuous after irradn., as the elements gold and oxygen from the substrate were detected by XPS. SEM images also show a roughened surface after irradn. The results strongly indicate that CH3NH3PbI3 is sensitive to the laser irradn. and that the light induced decompn. is a self-limiting process.

Solar cells based on org.-inorg. perovskite materials have dramatically developed in just a short period of time because of efficient light absorption and their unique semiconducting nature. The best power conversion efficiency is continuously recorded via various approaches; devices from sensitized mesoporous structures to planar structures, modified compn. of perovskite, and fabrication methods. Despite the amazing improvement, many groups have encountered low reproducibility and lower device efficiency than reported results because of the perovskite's own instability and sensitivity under ambient conditions; thus, we need a realistic and exptl. investigation. In this study, we compare soln. processing representative fabrication methods, which influence the growth, crystal orientation, and the electronic properties of CH3NH3PbI3, device reproducibility, and efficiency in planar perovskite solar. This comparative study gives a realistic overview of the fabrication methods for planar perovskite solar cells.

Quantum dot photovoltaics (QDPV) offer the potential for low-cost solar cells. To develop strategies for continued improvement in QDPVs, a better understanding of the factors that limit their performance is essential. Here, the authors study carrier recombination processes that limit the power conversion efficiency of PbS QDPVs. The authors demonstrate radiative sub-bandgap states and sub-bandgap state filling in operating devices by using photoluminescence (PL) and electroluminescence (EL) spectroscopy. These sub-bandgap states are most likely the origin of the high open-circuit-voltage (VOC) deficit and relatively limited carrier collection that have thus far been obsd. in QDPVs. Combining these results with the perspectives on recent progress in QDPV, eliminating sub-bandgap states in PbS QD films has the potential to show a greater gain than may be attainable by optimization of interfaces between QDs and other materials. The authors suggest possible future directions that could guide the design of high-performance QDPVs.

The rapid development of perovskite solar cells has focused its attention on defects in perovskites, which are gradually realized to strongly control the device performance. A fundamental understanding is therefore needed for further improvement in this field. Recent efforts have mainly focused on minimizing the surface defects and grain boundaries in thin films. Using time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy, we show that bulk defects in perovskite samples prepd. using vapor assisted soln. process (VASP) play a key role in addn. to surface and grain boundary defects. The defect state d. of samples prepd. at 150 °C (∼1017 cm-3) increases by 5 fold at 175 °C even though the av. grains size increases slightly, ruling out grain boundary defects as the main mechanism for the obsd. differences in PL properties upon annealing. Upon surface passivation using water mols., the PL intensity and lifetime of samples prepd. at 200 °C are only partially improved, remaining significantly lower than those prepd. at 150 °C. Thus, the present study indicates that the majority of these defect states obsd. at elevated growth temps. originates from bulk defects and underscores the importance to control the formation of bulk defects together with grain boundary and surface defects to further improve the optoelectronic properties of perovskites.

Investigating the stability and evaluating the quality of the CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite structures is quite crit. both to the design and fabrication of high-performance perovskite devices and to fundamental studies of the photophysics of the excitons. In particular, it is known that, under ambient conditions, CH3NH3PbI3 degrades producing some PbI2. We show here that low temp. Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy is a powerful tool to detect PbI2 traces in hybrid perovskite layers and single crystals. Because PL spectroscopy is a signal detection method on a black background, small PbI2 traces can be detected, when other methods currently used at room temp. fail. Our study highlights the extremely high stability of the single crystals compared to the thin layers and defects and grain boundaries are thought to play an important role in the degrdn. mechanism.

Correa-Baena, Juan-Pablo; Saliba, Michael; Buonassisi, Tonio; Graetzel, Michael; Abate, Antonio; Tress, Wolfgang; Hagfeldt, Anders

A review is given. The efficiencies of perovskite solar cells have gone from single digits to a certified 22.1% in a few years' time. At this stage of their development, the key issues concern how to achieve further improvements in efficiency and long-term stability. We review recent developments in the quest to improve the current state of the art. Because photocurrents are near the theor. max., our focus is on efforts to increase open-circuit voltage by improving charge-selective contacts and charge carrier lifetimes in perovskites via processes such as ion tailoring. The challenges assocd. with long-term perovskite solar cell device stability include the role of testing protocols, ionic movement affecting performance metrics over extended periods of time, and detn. of the best ways to counteract degrdn. mechanisms.

High efficiency stable inverted perovskite solar cells without current hysteresis
Wu, Chun-Guey; Chiang, Chien-Hung; Tseng, Zong-Liang; Nazeeruddin, Md. K.; Hagfeldt, Anders; Gratzel, Michael
Energy & Environmental Science
